docs.lead_paragraph: WITH ALL THE terrible images we have accumulated of Afghanistan -- killing and drugs and corruption and cruelty to women -- most people might wonder why the country cast such a spell on generations of travelers, adventurers, aid workers and seekers. When asked to explain themselves back home, these enchanted wanderers usually stutter something inadequate like ''Oh, the mountains'' or ''The people, they're so hospitable and proud.'' And as their friends and families listen skeptically, they will be busy devising a way to go back. Karen Woo was one of them, a young English doctor who went to Afghanistan in 2009 to visit her boyfriend, who was working there. They broke up; but Karen was smitten by the Afghans. In the week she was there, she visited a charity for street children and toured hospitals. She was appalled by the desperate need and wanted to help.
docs.snippet: A young English doctor’s Afghan adventure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress approved yet another temporary spending bill, which amounts to a budget cut, given rising costs.
docs.snippet: Congress approved yet another temporary spending bill, which amounts to a budget cut, given rising costs.
